response.raw:
Here is my attempt at the task, following the specified output format and rules:

Preparing Exhibits for Trial

1. Gather all potential exhibits, including documents, photographs, physical evidence, etc. Create an inventory list of every item. 2. Review each exhibit for relevance, authenticity, and admissibility. Set aside any exhibits that may not be usable. Consult with the attorney on any questionable items. 3. Organize the exhibits in a logical order, such as chronologically or by topic. Number each exhibit accordingly. Create an exhibit list with descriptions of each item. 4. Label each physical exhibit with an exhibit sticker showing the assigned exhibit number. For documents, apply exhibit stickers to the front or use exhibit stamps on each page. 5. Make copies of each document exhibit for the judge, opposing counsel, and witnesses. Prepare tabbed exhibit binders as needed. Ensure the original exhibits are safely stored and transported to court. 6. Enter the exhibit list and exhibit details into the firm's case management system and trial presentation software. Work with the trial tech to ensure digital exhibits are ready to present in court. 7. Prepare cover sheets to attach to each exhibit or group of exhibits, indicating the exhibit numbers, date, and other key information for quick identification during trial. 8. Assist the attorney in preparing witnesses to testify about the exhibits. Have exhibits on hand during witness prep sessions. 9. Transport exhibits to the courtroom before trial begins. Provide copies of the exhibit list and exhibit binders to the judge, court clerk, and opposing counsel per court procedures. Be prepared to hand exhibits to witnesses during trial as needed.
response.extracted:
Preparing Exhibits for Trial

1. Gather all potential exhibits, including documents, photographs, physical evidence, etc. Create an inventory list of every item. 2. Review each exhibit for relevance, authenticity, and admissibility. Set aside any exhibits that may not be usable. Consult with the attorney on any questionable items. 3. Organize the exhibits in a logical order, such as chronologically or by topic. Number each exhibit accordingly. Create an exhibit list with descriptions of each item. 4. Label each physical exhibit with an exhibit sticker showing the assigned exhibit number. For documents, apply exhibit stickers to the front or use exhibit stamps on each page. 5. Make copies of each document exhibit for the judge, opposing counsel, and witnesses. Prepare tabbed exhibit binders as needed. Ensure the original exhibits are safely stored and transported to court. 6. Enter the exhibit list and exhibit details into the firm's case management system and trial presentation software. Work with the trial tech to ensure digital exhibits are ready to present in court. 7. Prepare cover sheets to attach to each exhibit or group of exhibits, indicating the exhibit numbers, date, and other key information for quick identification during trial. 8. Assist the attorney in preparing witnesses to testify about the exhibits. Have exhibits on hand during witness prep sessions. 9. Transport exhibits to the courtroom before trial begins. Provide copies of the exhibit list and exhibit binders to the judge, court clerk, and opposing counsel per court procedures. Be prepared to hand exhibits to witnesses during trial as needed.
